pr_title: AuditLog: Refactor to use AuditCategory enum

timeline.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: I ve considered using this but i felt it was not efficient to loop through the list twice again to filter and convert to set. I would prefer more traditional approach for doing this (removing stream api itself). What do you think?
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: There will be no additional iterations over the stream (the only one is when it is consumed in the collect()), so it would be as efficient as forEach().
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
Yes. I thought of ignoring the second loop.
I have updated to use stream api
replies.author: sujithvm

timeline.bodyText: I am not sure that it is sufficient to log an error message and continue. It is possible that a category has a typo that causes parsing exception and it may go unnoticed (lost in log files).
timeline.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
I believe if we can recover from some error, then complain and recover. I hope error logs are not that casually ignored.
In this case, if incorrect category is provided, simply complain and recover from it.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: Imagine that the AuditCategory is constructed using a call to REST API from curl and somebody mistypes a category name. The return code of REST API would be 200 and the user who called REST API would assume that it succeeded and even not bother to look at the error log.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
That should directly return a bad request if you are trying to make a log message for an incorrect category type.
We can try to convert to Enum and then throw error in the validator of that rest api handler.  Not sure if we should handle it here.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: In the example, I refer to constructing EnumSet<AuditCategory> from a string passed as REST API parameter, not to constructing AuditMessage with an invalid AuditCategory.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
Alright. Do you want to throw exception here instead ? Or
Use something like:
        return categories
                .stream()
                .filter(Objects::nonNull)
                .map(String::toUpperCase)
                .map(AuditCategory::valueOf)
                .collect(Collectors.toCollection(() -> set));

And let java throw the IllegalArgumentException ?
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: This way, it will throw exception and prevent the service from starting up if elasticsearch.yml is configured incorrectly and can also assert for exceptions in REST api validators and throw bad request appropriately.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: It is OK to rely on valueOf() to throw an IllegalArgumentException or to convert it to a checked exception. I am slightly more inclined to IllegalArgumentException.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: AuditCategory::valueOf will throw IllegalArgumentException if cannot be converted to enum. Am I missing something?
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: @vrozov The current behavior is to actually post error and ignore invalid enum and have some tests to do so.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText:
AuditCategory::valueOf will throw IllegalArgumentException if cannot be converted to enum. Am I missing something?

No. I was referring to the same.

The current behavior is to actually post error and ignore invalid enum and have some tests to do so

IMO, there is a problem with an approach that tries to correct an invalid input. At a minimum, AuditCategory should allow a caller to get the list of categories that were not parsed or throw an exception.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: Can we have this when we need it?
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: What is your concern? Changing tests?
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: I meant to say, lets do it when we have a use-case ready. For sure, this will come up in future and let's target it that time. Maybe we will have more requirements.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: Could you explain the rationale/use-case for including this now? I think we are not on the same page. Where and what do you want do with string values that cannot be parsed ?
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: The current behavior is to ignore an invalid value and continue. The invalid value may come from a configuration file (the only way supported now) or from an API call with a request to update/change configuration (in the future). In both cases, likely a user (system admin) made a mistake and simply mistyped valid  audit category name that the user (system admin) wants to be in effect. How quickly the user (system admin) may realize that the system ignored or partially ignored the input is questionable.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: Note that the original code provided a better hint in the logging message of what setting has an unknown/invalid category. It may be good to keep it the same way should you decide to keep the existing behavior.  It is not necessary to log the InvalidArgumentException message.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: I will revert to throwing exception and will update tests to check for exception.
replies.author: sujithvm

timeline.bodyText: Consider using Iterable or Collection instead of a List. There is no need to know size(), so Iterable (preferred) or Collection should be sufficient.

timeline.bodyText: Consider making it private static in AuditCategory.

timeline.bodyText: No need to create new ArrayList. Use original return from settings.getAsList(key, defaultList) and Collections.emptyList() instead of clearing a new one.
timeline.author: vrozov

timeline.bodyText: My understanding is that not all AuditCategory applies to Rest or Transport categories. It may be good to log a warning if an admin tries to disable auditing for a category that does not apply. Note that this case is different from an invalid category.
timeline.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: Maybe raise another issue for this?
replies.author: sujithvm

timeline.bodyText: I'd recommend start deprecating "NONE" as a setting and log a warning. It is easy to use "none" instead of "NONE" especially that category names are case-insensitive.
timeline.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: Then it should complain and throw exception. It is documented to use NONE https://opendistro.github.io/for-elasticsearch-docs/docs/security-audit-logs/#exclude-categories

replies.bodyText: OK, I'll file an issue and see what others think.

timeline.bodyText: nit: as you are constructing an empty EnumSet directly here, add disabledRestCategoriesList.isEmpty() condition.
timeline.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
Do you mean disabledRestCategoriesList.isEmpty() || disabledRestCategoriesList.size() == 1 && "NONE".equalsIgnoreCase(disabledRestCategoriesList.get(0)) ?
Is it not redundant? as it will go to else and build an empty set.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: It is not redundant, but, yes, the end result is the same. Question is if you short-circuit call to parse() when disabledRestCategoriesList is implicitly empty, why is it not short-circuited when it is explicitly empty?
replies.author: vrozov

timeline.bodyText: Is it necessary to allow null? Should it check for an empty collection and throw NullPointerException?
timeline.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText: I don't think so. As far as this parse is concerned, absence of values in input (whether null || empty) should mean no output categories.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: While you may handle null the same way as an empty collection, the parse() function itself follows "prefer empty collection over null" and converts null to an empty set.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
I didnt quite follow you.
If we have an input list of nulls, since we are filtering non-nulls in the stream we would return empty set.
This is what I meant by absence of values and we are return an empty set. [null, null...] = null => return empty set.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText:
What if the collection categories itself is null? When I referred to "check for an empty collection" I meant instead of if (categories == null), check if (categories.isEmpty()).
You brought a good question, how null should be handled inside the collection. IMO, that is a programming mistake to pass null inside the categories collection.
replies.author: vrozov

replies.bodyText:
Are you saying to short-circuit if (categories == null || categories.isEmpty())  ?
I mean to say, absence of values whether categories is null or empty or list of only null strings should all mean the same thing -> empty category set.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: @vrozov If you could tell exactly the change you are looking for, i could can do that and move on. I don't want to be blocked with such issues.
replies.author: sujithvm

replies.bodyText: My suggestion is not to allow null at all, whether the collection itself is null or it contains null. Change if (categores == null) to if (categories.isEmpty()) and remove the filter.
